awd_titl_txt: Postdoctoral Fellow with an Interdisciplinary Approach to Law and Society
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Postdoctoral Fellow with an Interdisciplinary Approach to Law and Society

Abstract

To facilitate greater intellectual collaboration among the existing set of socio-legal scholars at Tulane University, this project will support a postdoctoral fellow in law and society whose research takes an interdisciplinary approach to legal studies. The postdoctoral fellow would be embedded within the research and scholarly community at Tulane University. The postdoctoral fellow will receive mentoring from senior faculty, participate in an interdisciplinary scholarly community, and mentor undergraduate student research assistants.

This project will nurture a scholar in law and society studies by fostering close research, mentoring, and networking interactions. Interdisciplinary scholarship in law and society takes place within several disciplines, including law, sociology, political science, psychology, and anthropology. Thus, this project will facilitate the intellectual development of the law and society communities at Tulane University by expanding the university's capacity, with a goal of drawing a diverse assembly of scholars, policy makers, and the legal community to its base in New Orleans.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project were to hire a postdoctoral fellow in law and society, support their research in the field of law and social sciences with an intersectional approach, and have them contribute to the law and social sciences community. Opportunities such as this post-doctoral fellowship aim to nurture young scholars whose work takes an intersectional approach to the study of law and social sciences, providing them with time and space to do their research, and mentoring them to launch successful careers. Encouraging these scholars has the potential to result in shifts in education, legal culture, and potentially legal outcomes. Tulane is committed to growing the pool of scholars whose work focuses on intersectional approaches and to nurturing their success over a lifetime.

Anne McGlynn-Wright was in residence for two years and advanced several research projects. She conducted research, published articles, and presented at conferences, focusing her work on two main subject areas: pregnancy, poverty, and privacy; and race, policing, and school suspensions. McGlynn-Wright?s main research project involved the development of the article ?Inspecting the Expecting: How Ideas about Pregnancy have Influenced the Development of U.S. Food Assistance? (currently under review). Her research agenda centers on the complex and intersectional ways that ideas about race, gender, poverty, and pregnancy status influence policy development with a focus on those policies that surveil and control individuals? lives and bodies. She also published work in the journal Social Problems on ?The Usual, Racialized, Suspects: The Consequence of Police Contacts with Black and White Youth on Adult Arrest.? Her work identifies the long-term effects of punishment by race. Overall, McGlynn-Wright?s research agenda shows the enormous value of looking at social problems intersectionally, in her case, looking at how race, class, gender, and in some cases, region (i.e. the South) combine to produce racial disparities in birth outcomes, food insecurity, or educational outcomes.
